block.p: LEAD: Markets
LEAD: Markets
Markets

The Nasdaq composite index has quietly moved within a whisker of its record high, showing the extent of the spring rally in stocks. The prices of nearly 28 percent of the more than 4,000 over-the-counter stocks are above their highs of 1987. [ Page D1. ] The Economy

Human telephone operators are rapidly disappearing, replaced by equipment that can recognize and mimic the human voice. Several regional and local telephone companies expect cost savings from the new electronic operators. [ A1. ]
More than 1,000 manufacturers promoted new inventions and innovations at the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago. [ D5. ] The Media Business

A Time-Paramount merger would create a ''debt-ridden monster,'' asserts Warner's chairman, Steven J. Ross. [ D1. ] Time and Warner are expected to call separate board meetings to approve a counterattack on Paramount's $10.7 billion hostile bid for Time. [ D3. ] Time's eight outside directors are likely to play a pivotal role in a battle for the company. [ D3. ]

A chain of free weekly newspapers plans to compete with The St. Louis Post-Dispatch for color circulars and classified advertising on Sundays. Experts say the concept, if successful, may be copied in other cities. [ D1. ]

A Supreme Court decision has set the stage for a reassessment of the ownership of billions of dollars in reproduction rights. The ruling expanded the rights of freelance photographers, writers and artists to ownership of their works. [ D12. ]
The resurgence of independent bookstores has encouraged publishing houses to produce books that may lack the mass-market appeal favored by the big chains. Publishing. [ D12. ]

MTV has offered viewers an island, a trailer park and even a new identity in its extravagant and successful promotions. [ D12. ] Cable TV franchises are facing competition from ''wireless'' cable companies that transmit programming over the air. [ D12. ]

Three Doyle Graf Raj executives walked out, accusing the chief executive of trying to find a buyer after agreeing to sell the agency to them. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D10. ] International Report

Hyperinflation is pushing Argentina into a depression, new figures indicate. An inflation rate of 12,000 percent has been forecast for this year. [ D4. ] At Argentina's mint, the presses have broken under the strain of printing more money. As the notes plunge in value, larger and larger denominations are planned. [ D1. ]
American International Group's efforts to receive payment on a claim against Peru are being closely watched by overseas investors and the U.S. Government. [ D1. ]

Washington's failure to reduce the budget deficit is ''deplorable,'' the world's central bankers said. The language, in a report by the Bank for International Settlements, was unusually sharp. [ D2. ]

All of Spain seems to be under construction. The building frenzy is in anticipation of late 1992, when the European Community is to eliminate trade boundaries, Seville is to hold a world's fair and Barcelona will be the site of the Olympic Games. [ D4. ]
U.S. companies with operations in China are being urged to consider a variety of options. [ D5. ] Today's Columns
Long-term interest rates could fall further because of strong foreign and domestic demand for bonds, economists say. But a decline in short-term rates may be forestalled. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

A man considered a leading securities expert became the first lawyer to lose a major criminal trial stemming from the recent Wall Street scandals. Arthur L. Mathews defended Paul A. Bilzerian, who was convicted on nine counts. Business and the Law. [ D2. ]
CRS Sirrine's stock price has surged in anticipation of new efforts to fight acid rain. Market Place. [ D6. ]
